{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3348018,"name":null,"username":"RTP","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/76d3ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-30T21:50:35.836Z","cooked":"

The physical connections on our CAN chain break occasionally.
We currently use the above connectors and we e-tape them together or put them in a REV clip. When they break, normally a ferrule comes out of the black terminal. We hot glued some of those points so they’re less likely to fall out.
We use the above red butt connectors from Home Depot when the CAN wires break but wires have fallen out of those connectors a few times. We’ve also hot glued those. What suggestions do you have to make our system more reliable? Is soldering better?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-30T21:50:35.836Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1448,"reads":511,"readers_count":510,"score":7342.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1229/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PWM Cable Clip - 10 Pack - REV Robotics","clicks":44}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63967,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3348024,"name":"Ariel","username":"ArielSR71","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arielsr71/{size}/212430_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-30T22:08:23.089Z","cooked":"

I know that both my teams use Wago type connectors for CAN, idk the exact model, and they’ve been good afaik even after rough matches.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-30T22:08:40.310Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":486,"readers_count":485,"score":217.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"Ariel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41460,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9739 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/2","custom_user_title":"9739 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348039,"name":"","username":"FinIce","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/finice/{size}/270519_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-30T22:23:19.503Z","cooked":"

Soldering is definitely better than hot glue for repairing wires. I know some teams just solder their entire CAN.

We have been using the Molex SL Connectors and 2 pin wagos from WCP, and they have been great so far.

Repair I would go with solder, but Connectors is a toss-up between Molex and Wago.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-30T22:23:19.503Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":65,"reads":476,"readers_count":475,"score":425.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52870,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Amateur Historian?"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/3","custom_user_title":"Amateur Historian?","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348042,"name":"Drakxii","username":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-30T22:25:51.770Z","cooked":"

I have found it hard to get reliable crimps on butt connectors, so if you are willing to use that kind of connection I would highly recommend solder splices like these Amazon.com over butt connectors.

Also the crimp that goes into the black boxes is not a ferrule, it’s a pin crimp.

We use WCP-0486 and haven’t had any issues.

Much easier than soldering.

Many hats"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/5","custom_user_title":"2141 & 21579. Many hats","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348117,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T00:28:36.599Z","cooked":"

We gave up on connectors for CAN a couple of years ago. Now, we just solder all CAN connections and shrink tube over the join. It’s the most reliable way to ensure you never lose a CAN connection and it’s easily repaired/replaced if you have to cut it for some reason (replacing a damaged motor or CANcoder, for instance.) Teach your electrical team to solder properly and you’ll never go back to connectors.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-31T00:28:36.599Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":52,"reads":419,"readers_count":418,"score":418.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"Stewart Riley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32783,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I plan, therefore I am"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/6","custom_user_title":"I plan, therefore I am","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348123,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T00:32:21.452Z","cooked":"

Use Molex SL connectors. These look outwardly similar to the connectors you are using but have an integrated latch and are also polarized. I like to buy them from Hansen Hobbies, where they are sold as “LP” connectors. .100" (2.54mm) Latching Polarized (LP) Connector Housings, Terminals, and Headers

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-31T00:32:21.452Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":395,"readers_count":394,"score":189.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"http://www.hansenhobbies.com/products/connectors/pt1inlpconnectors/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":".100" (2.54mm) Latching Polarized (LP) Connector Housings, Terminals, and Headers","clicks":175}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/7","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348139,"name":"Jai Gupta","username":"jaigupta13","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T01:08:01.252Z","cooked":"

I highly recommend Molex SL. We have not had a single issue with them in 2 years. We recommend a model with the TPA feature. Details and part numbers are on our build thread.

FRC 3061 Huskie Robotics - 2024 Season Build Thread Open Alliance
CAN and Low Power Connector Solution What connector to use for CAN is a perennial question. Our answer is Molex SL. We have had 100% reliability since we were introduced to Molex SL connectors around 3 years ago. Not one crimp has failed in over a thousand. We achieve this through solid part selection, training, procedure, and inspection. Part selection: The crimper we use is part 638118700. We recommend the official crimper for the best crimps. You can get the crimper in the FIRST Choice Molex…
","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-31T01:08:01.252Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":376,"readers_count":375,"score":185.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"Jai Gupta","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-3061-huskie-robotics-2024-season-build-thread/447553/21","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 3061 Huskie Robotics - 2024 Season Build Thread","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59344,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348153,"name":"Taegen P","username":"tmpoles","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tmpoles/{size}/156834_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T01:33:09.503Z","cooked":"

This year, we have swapped our entire canbus to WAGO connectors. It has made for incredibly easy maintenance (got a major mech that needs to come off for a robot repair? Don’t need to cut the wires unlike solder), and after having a pretty major electrical repair to do last year during an event, we used a bunch of these to fix.

It also works for series and star topography teams - you can use either in lines or the horizontal connectors. Purchasable from REV, but we just get them from Amazon to be honest.

One caveat is that I would highly recommend putting ferrules on the ends, and then placing them in the wago. Can wire is pretty fragile at times and a well crimped ferrule on it does wonders.

Molex connectors also fabulous, but we didn’t have the good crimper to use right away so it’s not standardized for us yet.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-31T01:34:09.693Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":352,"readers_count":351,"score":185.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"Taegen P","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21565,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4476 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/9","custom_user_title":"4476 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348154,"name":"Tauseef Afraz","username":"TFM110","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tfm110/{size}/197758_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T01:33:46.613Z","cooked":"
FinIce:

Repair I would go with solder

I personally disagree. Depending on your setup, if you cut your cables short then solder, you will have a really tough time replacing and resoldering, especially with a bunch of mechanisms.

I prefer the WCP CAN Lever Nut connectors. They are simply and easy to use, and in my opinion, easier to replace

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-31T01:33:46.613Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":335,"readers_count":334,"score":142.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"Tauseef Afraz","primary_group_name":"Swyft-Robotics","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39084,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC5431AM | FRC5790M| FUN | SWYFT"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/10","custom_user_title":"FRC5431AM | FRC5790M| FUN | SWYFT","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348155,"name":"","username":"Vasista","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T01:35:00.919Z","cooked":"

I like 2 in 4 out lever nuts https://www.amazon.com/GKEEMARS-Connectors-Connector-Conductor-Terminal/dp/B08JPBJDW4
for sensor power and CAN. You can easily split sensor power to more sensors with this. And for trunk and branch CAN, you can split the branch off easily.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-31T01:35:00.919Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":326,"readers_count":325,"score":125.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460744,"topic_slug":"robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/GKEEMARS-Connectors-Connector-Conductor-Terminal/dp/B08JPBJDW4","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com","clicks":97}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39370,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer"},"post_url":"/t/robust-canbus-wire-connector-suggestions/460744/11","custom_user_title":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3348178,"name":"","username":"FinIce","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/finice/{size}/270519_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-31T02:00:50.484Z","cooked":"

Fair enough, it really is a lot more naunced than I made it seem.

As you described, if you have a tight setup where it needs to be effectively a wire, I would solder, or try and replace the wire.

If you have the time, but have less space, then Molex or something else is great, if this area constantly separates I have found less issues with the Molex grabbing. Making the area that gets split replaceable is a good move.

If you need quick, dirty and simple, or you dont really have any constraints, then Wago is great.

Personally I always go for Wago, but recently have increased on Molex. Looking back, I would just replace a wire if I needed to solder, although I usually have enough slack to slap a connector in.

We just plug things together for prototyping, but usually do a soldered CAN bus before going to events. For repairs, we might use WAGOs to save time.

I’m going to echo the sentiment for Molex SL series connectors.

We just posted our write up on how we do CAN with the 3 pin SL connectors here:

FRC 2846 FireBears | 2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance Open Alliance
CAN Connectors Standard Connectors: If you struggle with your CAN connectors, listen up! Our team hasn’t used the standard connectors for years, but a lot of teams still do. The reason we stopped is, first of all, because they come apart very easily. To keep the connectors together teams will use electrical tape or a clip, but neither are reliable so they’ll still disconnect in the robot. It’s also super easy to accidentally plug them in green-to-yellow in a rush. [image] Locking Connectors: W…

We had issues with Wago lever nuts. Both 3175 Knight Vision and 1189 Gearheads both spoke with our electrical captain and we decided in future we will solder all CAN connections or if we do use a connector for a quick fix, use a Dupont style it will be the Molex with clips. We lost half of our motor controllers mid match when our pigeons green can wire tore out of a lever nut after a hard hit.

CANLatching800×1112 239 KB

From this thread here:

FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2023 Build Thread Open Alliance
The Right Tool for the (Wiring) Job When we were a rookie team and money was extremely tight, we made do with a very basic set of electrical tools. Even then, though, we spent the $50 or so for a TriCrimp because we knew we were going to use it a lot. It does just one thing - attach PowerPole terminals - but does that one thing nearly perfectly. In fact, as far as I’m aware, we have never had an on-robot failure of a PowerPole crimp made with this tool. Plus it’s pretty easy to teach student…

We did pickup the crimping kit as part of FIRST Choice so we can make those connectors next season if we go down that road

In addition when you are using spark maxes it was recommended to hot glue encoder and other types of connectors into their ports, both the JST hall effects and encoder breakout boards. This also can supply some strain relief if components mounting fails. The wires are less likely to yank out in that scenario. The CAN into the spark Max is a jst as well so… Glue it down!

kingc95:

Glue it down!

This is solid advice for any connector and connection. We’re pretty much at the “if it can come out, it probably will at some point, so just hot glue that thing to be sure it doesn’t” stage. It’s worth it for the peace of mind alone.

We use these: Amazon.com

If you’re planning on using any lever wire connectors, I would recommend hot gluing your connections.

We have used these blade-splice connectors for two years now and quite like them. They are easy to install and can be quickly cut-out if they need to be replaced. While still not as compact as soldering and heatshrink on connections, it is significantly more compact than lever nuts, and they also come in a T version for short CAN branches. You just put in your unstripped wire and crush the cover down with pliers, and the blades in the connector penetrate the insulation and make a connection.

image1034×766 77.1 KB

https://www.amazon.com/Low-Voltage-Electronic-connectors-Solderless/dp/B072P15279
